characters: SLUT ATTACKING MY CAR WITH HER STUPID PURSE

dialogues.speaker: LAURA PICKLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What’s our secret? We can only see her from behind, but the SAD SACKS that descend on the opposing escalator seem to be in AWE. She steps off, but we stay on the ESCALATOR - INT. LAND O’LAKES DAIRY FACILITY — DES MOINES, IOWA A CONVEYOR BELT in a high-tech dairy. An oblivious COW rolls by. LAURA (V.O., CONT’D) Our secret is simple: We are the best. Bob carves butter better than anyone. Better than Ned Eaton, better than Carol Ann Stevenson, and certainly better than that girl. The conveyor belt STOPS. The cow looks at us, quizzically A machine WHIRLS up and milk begins to flow through clear tubes. LAURA (V.O, CONT’D) And it used to be that in this country the best always won. ASSEMBLY LINE — STICK after STICK of yellow BUTTER floats by on a conveyo belt. We move in on one sad, deformed stick of butter. LAURA (V.O., CONT’D) Well, times have changed. Another WORKER grabs the deformed stick of butter and throws it in the TRASH. EXT. CORNFIELD — IOWA — DAY A YOUNG BLACK GIRL rides her bike down a long dirt drivew toward a yellow house. She has multi-colored barrettes in her hair and a white wicker basket attached to her bike. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is DESTINY, age 12. She’s adorable.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY, (V.O)
dialogues.text: If you can believe it, the first time I saw Mrs. Pickler I actually wished she and Mr. Pickler would take me in. The foster people had just put me with a bunch of families and anyone had to be better than them. INT. MOORE HOME — SAME Destiny sits at a long wooden table with sixteen identica blonde kids. They look like a cult. DESTINY (V.O., CONT’D) First was the Moore’s. They were home- schoolers, which always spells trouble -

dialogues.speaker: MRS. MOORE
dialogues.text: (to Destiny and the 16 kids) Then God cast down the angels and they fell to Earth which is where dinosaur bones come from! Destiny, scared, bulges her eyes. EXT. MOORE HOME — LATER Destiny drives off in a non-descript GOVERNMENT CAR. A STATE SEAL on the car door reads “Iowa Dept. of Human Services.”

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Next came Mrs. Carmichael. She was on pills... EXT. MEDICAL BUILDING — DAY A WRECK of a woman, JUNE CARMICHAEL, sits in the front se of her car, smoking.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE
dialogues.text: Just tell the doctor you’ve been anxious lately and you need Klonopin. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Okay. Klonopin.

dialogues.speaker: JUNE
dialogues.text: (touched) You’re going to be such a good daughter. Destiny exits the car. Mrs. Carmichael pops a few pills a smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY, (V.O)
dialogues.text: I liked her. She was always so calm. EXT. MRS.CARMICHAEL’S CONDO — NIGHT A POLICE OFFICER pushes June Carmichael into the back of cruiser, while another Police Officer leads Destiny to th same Government Car with the STATE SEAL we saw earlier. DESTINY (V.O., CONT’D) But she got arrested, so after that came The Gundersons. They were old and they only took me in so someone would be home just in case something happened. INT. THE GUNDERSON HOME — LATER Tons of DOILES everywhere. MRS. GUNDERSON, 100+, shows Destiny one of those telephones with GIANT BUTTONS.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GUNDERSON
dialogues.text: (shouting) The red button is for the ambulance! Destiny looks at the phone. EXT. THE GUNDERSON HOMES — LATER PARAMEDICS wheel two bodies into an AMBULANCE. Destiny looks on wearing her pj’s.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So you can understand why I wasn’t onto Mrs. Pickler’s bull sooner. Plus I was only 12 at the time. Now that I’m 13 I know the truth: white people are weirdos. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ambulance pulls away leaving Destiny all alone in the middle of the night, at some weird house, in some weird town. OPENING TITLES — Butter: Pickler Vs. Destiny Over the credits: GIANT IMAGINARY BUTTER SCULPTURES rise out of the cornfields like the statues at Easter Island - Johnny Appleseed, Paul Bunyon, The Liberty Bell, Celine Dion, Nancy Reagan, etc. INT. IOWA STATE DEPT. OF HUMAN SERVICE — CHILDREN’S TRANSITIONARY HOME — NIGHT A cinderblock building. Destiny enters. In the background we see the same government car with the STATE SEAL pull away. A WOMAN works the reception desk. Without looking up, she hands Destiny a key.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Your room’s still empty.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Any word from my mom yet? The woman looks up to Destiny. We know the answer and so does Destiny. Destiny, resigned, walks down the nondescript hallway. DESTINY’S ‘ROOM’ AT THE CENTER — LATER Like a cell. The blanket looks itchy and the walls are bare. Destiny puts her SUITCASE neatly in the corner. She doesn’t bother unpacking... she’1l1 just have to pack up again in a few days anyway. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. PIONEER HALL — IOWA STATE FAIR — DAY A grand hall PACKED with ONLOOKERS. Thousands of them. By the way people are acting, you’d think they’re at the Sup Bowl. A sign above reads: “MASTERY IN BUTTER COMPETTITION” The hall is lined with several glass-fronted coolers, eac housing a sculpture made of pure butter: Elvis Presley, a milking cow, Harry Potter’s broom, Dale Earnhardt, Jr., etc.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA PICKLER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: As you know, my husband Bob is a visionary in the field of butter artistry. Obviously I'm aware the idea of butter sculpting can cause people to sneer or snicker but did you know that more people visited the butter sculptures at the Iowa State Fair last year than saw Celine Dion’s farewell tour in Las Vegas or attended the World Series... combined? Of course you didn’t. How could you with the liberal media as biased as it is? A huge CROWD has formed around one sculpture in particula a life-sized replica of- LAURA (V.O., CONT’D) And yes, Bob took home the blue ribbon again like he had each year for the past 20 years. DA VINCI’S LAST SUPPER - From afar, the sculpture looks ridiculous. But as we get closer, we see the exquisite detail of the CHALICE, the ROBES that flow right before o eyes, the quiver of fear in Jesus and the slight cock of Judas’ eyebrow. It’s truly a masterpiece. LAURA (V.O. CONT’D) The Des Moines Register even called him ‘The King Of Butter.’ A FINGER presses the ‘play’ button on an old boom box. Th theme from “Rocky” blares. A fog machine ramps up. A man Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: runs out to greet his public: BOB PICKLER - rock star, natural, and a god among men. CHEERS! The crowd freaks out. LAURA (V.O., CONT’D) Guess that kinda’ makes me the queen. AND THEN, as the fog parts, a woman emerges. This is LAUR PICKLER and her age is none of your business. LAURA (V.O., CONT’D) We had it all. FLASH BULBS! NEWS CAMERAS! The crowd is mesmerized by a smiling Bob and a waving Laura. They are Brad and Angelin of butter. INT. CHILDREN’S TRANSITIONAL HOME — SAME Destiny is in the TV room. ON TV — a NEWSCAST from the Iowa State Fair. A REPORTER interviews Bob and Laura standing beside Bob’s Last Suppe sculpture.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (to reporter) Of course the awards are wonderful, but what’s most satisfying to Bob and I is the attention we bring to our charity, Camp Butter, where we help children with special needs. CLOSE ON: Destiny as Laura mouths the words ‘special needs.’ She’s mesmerized as the happy couple laughs. Laur kisses Bob on the cheek. Bob kisses her back. They’re amazing. Destiny hops up. EXT. TRANSITIONAL CENTER — LATER Destiny unlocks her bike and takes off. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. 7-11 — LATER Destiny SLAPS a box of BUTTER onto the counter along with some money.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Mom ran out of butter in the middle of making hotcakes, huh?

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: I don’t have a mom. The Clerk looks at her, not knowing what to say.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: (sweetly) Thanks. Bye. Destiny races out, hops on her bike and takes off. INT. PIONEER HALL — IOWA STATE FAIR — LATER Destiny stares at Bob’s Last Supper sculpture. She runs h hands along the glass in awe. She reaches into her white wicker basket and pulls out a knife and her stick of butter (from 7-11). And then she begins carving. Slow at first. Then faster. Then faster. Then faster (we just see her face.) CLOSE ON: her carved stick of butter. It’s an exact, perfect replica of the CHALICE from Bob’s piece. It’s brilliant. LATER — Bob is surrounded by adoring women. He’s like a chubby, diabetic Zac Efron. Laura leers at them.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Being the wife of a celebrity, I was used to the way other women could get around my Bob. Less secure women might get jealous, but I never really felt threatened. I mean, considering the competition I didn’t really think I had anything to worry about- Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chunky woman wearing a homemade “I’m a Bob-Head” sweatshirt and nursing a Slurpee races up to Laura.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Carol Ann Stevenson! Why you look just amazing. Laura leans down and hugs the poor, sad thing. CAROL ANN STEVENSON is star-struck in the presence of Laura.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANN
dialogues.text: You really think so?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. I think it’s very brave of you to wear stirrup pants with your body type. Carol Ann looks down at her pants, insecure.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O)
dialogues.text: Which brings me to Destiny— LATER — Another crowd has formed around Bob. The guy is a people magnet. Bob leans down to Destiny and pats her on the hea He studies her tiny butter sculpture of the Chalice.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: This could be you up here next year. Destiny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Quiet one, aren’t ya’? Destiny shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: That's okay. John Wayne was quiet too. Bob leans down. He really is a good guy. Cheesy, but a go guy. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I expect to see you here competing next year, Destiny. Bob stands up, and pats her on the head. She’s kinda’ ove the moon.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Destiny. I think her parents were a little presumptuous naming her that, don’t you? Say what you will, but at least those people are creative with their names. Laura leers at Destiny, arms folded.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O., CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (forced) Still, I wish her the best. Bob leans down to hug Destiny. It’s one of those true, heartfelt, authentic hugs. And maybe, just for a second, catch of glimpse of Laura looking over in, dare it be sai awe. She hasn’t had a hug like that in years. EXT. EMMET FAMILY HOME — IOWA CITY - NIGHT A Volvo pulls into the driveway of a refurbished Victoria A BICYCLE (we remember it as Destiny’s bike with the basket) is attached to a bike rack in the back. INT. EMMET FAMILY HOME — BEDROOM - LATER An adorable girls’ bedroom. A woman, JILL EMMET, flips on the soft lights.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: This will be your bedroom. Destiny enters the room slowly. She’s never seen anything this nice.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: It's pink. A man, ETHAN EMMIT, puts his hand on Destiny’s shoulder. Ethan and Jill are white. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  10

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I told her to go with green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill looks at Ethan. The whole thing is kind of awkward.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: No. I think it’s pretty. Jill bends down and smiles at Destiny.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: This is your home now. You’re part of our family and we want you to be comfortable. Jill looks to Ethan: that was the right thing to say, right? Destiny sits down on the bed and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: There's a TV?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Oh, you can’t watch that past 8? Did we say 8?

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: 9. No TV past 9. (BEAT) Is there anything you need? You have sheets, towels are in the bath, anything? Destiny looks around.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: What do you like to do for fun? Hobbies? We can buy you some stuff.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: I’m not really that good at anything. Ethan looks to Jill: I have no idea how to talk to a twel year old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Oh, don’t say that. Everybody’s good at something.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Not me. My last mom said so.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: (heartbroken) Well you don’t have to worry about stuff like that anymore, okay?

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Okay. Jill lowers the lights and quietly shuts the door. INT. PIONEER HALL — BUTTER GALA - NIGHT The Pioneer hall has been transformed. A banner in the ba reads “Land 0’ Lakes Mastery in Butter Gala.” The whole thing looks like a sad prom. ORVAL ANDERSON, the white-haired main judge of the Iowa State Mastery in Butter Committee, is on a make-shift sta in front of a pull-down projection screen. We catch him mid-joke:

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: -and so Helen handed me the casserole and I took one bite and said ‘honey, I’m sorry, but I can believe it’s not butter.’ The crowd goes wild.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: But enough about me. Bob? Bob Pickler...? Stand up for us. Bob, in jeans and a t-shirt, stands. And then there’s Laura: in a glamorous pink evening gown that would make Alexis Carrington jealous. She stands and waves, apropos of nothing. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: Bob, when the Governor called me and asked what we could add to the upcoming Bicentennial Time Capsule I knew exactly what to do. Lower the lights, please. The lights lower and a crappy, homemade iMovie swirls on- screen. INSERT MOVIE: a BUTTER FAN talks to the camera. He holds meat-on-a-stick in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTTER FAN
dialogues.text: Let me put it this way. You’ve got your Michael Jordan. You’ve got your Tiger Woods, and you’ve got your Bob Pickler. (BEAT) I mean, Bob’s not black but you get my point. - Next, Carol Ann Stevenson, interviewed at home in front of her “Bob-Shrine”, speaks.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANN STEVENSON
dialogues.text: Oh, I come every year and that’s mainly because of Bob. Everyone knows he’s made butter what it is today. He’s hands-down the best. Not to mention the sexiest. (giggles) Oh my god, I did not just say that. (suddenly nervous) Wait, will Laura see this? Oh, you have to cut that part out. (BEAT) No, seriously. Carol Ann Stevenson stares at the camera, afraid for her life. - INSERT GRAINY VHS VIDEO — 1987- A YOUNGER BOB carves a butter sculpture of Ronald Reagan riding a horse. Bob put down his tools.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER BOB
dialogues.text: (waving to the camera) Whatdya’ think, hon? We hear Laura’s voice. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER LAURA
dialogues.text: Maybe more detail in the hands like we discussed? It has to be perfect. We're recording this for posterity. A YOUNGER LAURA, with bigger hair and shoulder pads spins the video recorder around (she’s holding it) and records herself. She seems more lighthearted and less intense.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER LAURA
dialogues.text: Hello posterity. How do you like my new dress? Younger Laura hands the camera to Bob and spins around, showing off her dress. She and Bob both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER BOB
dialogues.text: They better like it. It cost me 15 dollars. Younger Laura looks to the camera.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER LAURA
dialogues.text: I’m worth it. Laura smiles as Bob swoops into frame for a peck on the cheek. - Another man, NED EATON, speaks to the camera while carving a sculpture of his own.

dialogues.speaker: NED EATON
dialogues.text: My name is Ned Eaton and I’ve lost to Bob Pickler 16 times. He’s just that good. - The Butter Fan again, now standing with his BUTTER FAN WIFE. She has crispy hair.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTER FAN
dialogues.text: (excited) So it was '92 or '93-
Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: BUTTER FAN
dialogues.text: Yeah, ‘93 and Ned Eaton comes out with this amazing sculpture of this T-rex eating a little girl-

dialogues.speaker: BUTTER FAN WIFE
dialogues.text: It was beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTER FAN
dialogues.text: And so everyone is like, this guy is gonna’ finally knock Bob off his game. I mean, it was that good.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTER FAN WIFE
dialogues.text: It was like something you’d see in Europe. Just really, really elegant.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTER FAN
dialogues.text: So everyone’s real tense, right, and Bob just has this calm look on his face like a Jedi. And then he reveals his piece. Fricking Schindler’s List. INSERT: A video of Bob’s Schindler’s list sculpture. A ma made of butter, shakes his finger at two shamed Nazis. Bo finishes, tossing aside his carving tools like in a frenz

dialogues.speaker: BUTTER FAN WIFE
dialogues.text: Schindler’s List. It made me cry and I’m not even Jewish. - Ned Eaton speaks again.

dialogues.speaker: NED EATON
dialogues.text: - and carving butter is not easy. I mean, some of these jokesters come in here with an ‘I-can-do-that-too attitude’ and I just shake my head. I'd say the average male- the average North American male could carve maybe a circle or a tree if they’re lucky. A lot of these guys, these guys that carve duck decoys or the ladies that enter their pies- that’s kid’s stuff. But butter? Butter's hard because of the consistency. It’s not for lightweights. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 15 - Laura speaks. She’s in her living room, fresh flowers behind her and the shot is filmed with a soft-focus Vaseline lens.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: People laugh when I say this, but I think Bob and I could really parlay this fame we have from butter into politics. I mean, don’t be shocked if you see us in the governor’s mansion one day. This is just the beginning. (BEAT) We help children with special needs, you know. - The Butter Fan speaks again.

dialogues.speaker: BUTTER FAN
dialogues.text: Could someone ever beat Bob Pickler? No. No one’s ever gonna’ beat Bob Pickler. Nope. Not possible. Sorry. The iMovie ends (with the crappy “swirl” feature,) and th lights turn back on in the grand hall.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: Bob Pickler, ladies and gentlemen. 20 great years! Bob and Laura stand. And as the cameras flash we see this is where Laura shine she’s poised, confident, and absolutely stunning. She is the Queen of Butter and cherishes all the respect and adulation it affords. INT. EMMIT FAMILY HOME — NIGHT It’s dark, but nightlights line the hall. Destiny, in her pajamas, walks to

dialogues.speaker: THE KITCHEN
dialogues.text: She’s half-asleep but still pretty amazed. The fridge is stainless steel and everything is clean. The dishwasher even matches the cabinets. She opens the fridge and looks around inside. Nice food: apples, fancy olives, no sugary stuff. She looks in the door - Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 16 No butter, just Soy Spread. INT. PIONEER HALL — LATER The party seems to be winding down but Laura, ever the trooper, is posing for photos with a few kids with Downs Syndrome.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (shouting to the handicapped) I've always said your people are the small flashlight that helps a dark world find its lost car keys. With Laura distracted, Orval motions for Bob to come join him.

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE-
dialogues.text: Orval seems nervous.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: Listen. The panel’s been doing some talking and you've had a great run.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Twenty years.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: Twenty years. You’re a legend. You've been in Parade Magazine. You’re the Oprah of butter. But we just sort of feel that maybe it’s time to give someone else a shot, you know.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (not fully registering) Oh.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: Look, we're prepared to offer you a spot on the panel. You’1l be a judge. Along with me and Mary Alice and Carl Hudgins.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (shell-shocked) Carl Hudgens is a good guy. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bob snaps

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: Great guy. You’ve had a good run, Bob, but now it’s time to start giving back. Like Oprah does.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: She's got that Angel Network.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: It’s time, Bob. out of the shock of the moment and comes around.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Well, uh, sure. Oh yeah, sure. Of course. You know, I am getting old and you know, it really is important to pass the baton.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: Absolutely. But you know, I wanted to ask you a delicate question... Laura? GREAT HALL — Laura holds court with some female ADMIRERS.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Of course he would make an excellent mayor or even governor. If we can achieve excellence in one arena then we can certainly achieve it in another. That's just how life is. Successful people can be successful at anything. Her admirers nod in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: BACKSTAGE
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Right. Laura.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: Will she...? 17

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Oh, no.. it’s fine. It’s fine.. she’ll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: Just ‘cause I know she’s very ‘involved’.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: She'll be fine. Bob gulps. EXT. THE PICKLER FAMILY HOME — NIGHT A suburban home. It’s pretty peaceful until-

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (0.S)
dialogues.text: (screaming) Who the fuck do they think they are? INT. THE PICKLER FAMILY HOME — SAME Laura, still in her gown, is pacing around the living roo while Bob, with his head lowered, sits on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: This is wrong. This is so wrong. They can’t do this. We have rights. Their daughter KAITLEN, 17, watches her ‘episode’ — she’s been through it all before.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Laura, there’s no need to curse.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (more pacing) Clearly Orval wanted you out of the way. I’ve always known exactly what kind of person he is. Of course, I never thought he’d go this far but-

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You know Orval is a good man. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Don’t be so naive. He’s had it out for us from day one. (BEAT) I’1l call the governor. That's what I’1ll do.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: (deadpan) Or just go straight to Jesus? Laura looks to Kaitlen - and that’s all she needs to do t shut her up.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: My constitutional rights are being violated and I will call the governor. Get me the yellow pages. Bob looks up. He just has to say it.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: The governor doesn’t care, Laura. Laura WHIPS her head toward Bob, Jurassic Park-style.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (mumbling) The governor doesn’t care.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (closing in) Whose side are you on, Bob? They’re destroying everything we’ve worked so hard on for the last 20 years and you’re just going to take it?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It’s time to pass the baton, Laura. I need to start giving back. Like Oprah.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: How dare you bring Oprah into this? This is about me, you and butter. Bob peaks his head up. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You mean it’s about me and butter? Laura stops pacing: Oh, no he didn’t.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (sweetly) Kaitlen. Could you leave us, please? Kaitlen gets up and runs the hell upstairs.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: Cover your balls, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I know why this happened. You didn’t stand up for yourself again. That’s what happened, isn’t it?

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Can’t we just-

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I guess dad was right when he warned me against marrying someone whose biggest dream was to be a middle-school principal.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: What’s that supposed to mean?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It means I should’ve taken his advice and married Boyd Bolton. At least he inherited a successful Ford Dealership. Bob gets up and grabs his coat.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: I’m done.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I doubt Boyd would just give up Bolton Ford at the drop of a hat.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Laura, please. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 Bob opens the front door.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: What if Al Qaeda attacked Bolton Ford? Do you think Boyd would just throw in the towel? Just say ‘here terrorists, take the keys!? It’s all yours.’

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Laura. Al Qaeda is not going to attack Bolton Ford. Bob exits.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (shouting out the front door) No, Bob, he would’ve fought for it like a fucking man! Laura slams the door behind him. Bob peels out in his minivan. INT. EMMIT HOME — BATHROOM — NIGHT Destiny sits on the toilet. Just before she finishes peeing, she looks to the toilet paper holder: it’s empty. Destiny hobbles up and looks worried: she doesn’t know where these people keep their toilet paper. She opens a few cupboards: Nothing. Finally, she looks under the sink and spots a spare roll. Laura turns to see — Brooke, dressed in her stripper outfit from the night before. She saunters up to the table and removes her sunglasses.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (mortified) Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I want to sign up. Brooke gives Laura the evil-eye.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: For the Johnson County Mastery in Butter Sculpture Competition? Brooke laughs out loud.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Fuck. Oh, man. Yeah. That. I want to sign up for that. She looks over to Laura and mouths the word ‘I’m gonna’ c you.’

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Have you worked with butter before?

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh, I’ve worked with it all. Nancy slides over the sign up clipboard to Brooke. Laura walks over.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I object. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, I, um, she’s here on time and the rules say anyone can enter.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Look at what she’s wearing. Nancy furiously flips through the rule-book.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (nervous ) I don’t see anything about that in here. Brooke takes Laura aside.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Your husband owes me another 600 bucks.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Interesting. Did he buy 600 blow-jobs on credit? Brooke looks at her, impressed: I didn’t know you had it you.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You came in between me and my man.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Shh. We’re in a moose lodge. (BEAT) Bob is my husband. He cares about me. We built a life together. I bore his children

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: So? You want a cookie ‘cause you got pregnant? I get pregnant like once a month.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Do you honestly think you're anything more than a cheap lay to him? And do you think you were the first? (laughing) Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: 45 LAURA (CONT’D) You're just another in a long string of whores. Brooke is stunned. We can understand that maybe she’s actually developed feelings for Bob. And then Laura goes for the kill. LAURA (CONT’D) He’1l fuck you a couple more times and then he’1l get bored. And after that he’1l come right back where he belongs: in my house, on my sofa. Brooke sucks it up.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Listen. Does me being here piss you off in any way whatsoever?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Good. Brooke marches back over to the sign-up table and scribbl her name on the clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: It’s on, hussy. Brooke exits leaving a stunned room. INT. PICKLER FAMILY HOME — NIGHT Laura, Nancy (the sign-up lady) and Carol Ann Stevenson have tea in Laura’s living room.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I want her out. Nancy is nervous. Carol Ann is in full support of Laura.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, I- Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: This will go over very badly with the Land O’ Lakes people. Trust me. I’ve been around a long time and these corporate brass types do not stand for that kind of behavior. I mean, they could disqualify all of Johnson Country just on her outfit alone.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANN
dialogues.text: She is representing America’ favorite butter. Nancy stands up.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, but we can’t disqualify someone on the basis of — whatever that was. You’1ll just have to beat her fair and square. Carol Ann looks to Laura. Her teacup is shaking.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I’ll see you ladies at orientation. Nancy exits. There’s a slight pause. Carol Ann doesn’t kn what to say or do.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (through gritted teeth) Get out. Carol Ann gets up and runs out. INT. HY-VEE GROCERY STORE — DAY Laura, in high heels, pushes a shopping cart filled entirely with BUTTER. She gets a few strange looks.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s really sad that some people have nothing better to do with their time than to try and drag down others. Laura smiles to the CHECK-OUT GIRL. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 47 INT. PICKLER FAMILY HOME — BASEMENT — LATER Laura, inside their in-home butter cooler, molds cold butter in her hands. She wears goggles and an apron.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O., CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Especially people who are simply trying to work hard and spread a little light in this dark world. I mean, look at what they did to that Heather Mills. And to think, that poor thing only has one leg. Imagine what they’1l try to do to those of us who aren’t retarded. Laura studies a 70’s-looking book titled “You Too Can Be Artist!” She stares at her hunk of butter, focused. INT. CORAL RIDGE EPISCOPAL CHURCH — LATER Laura kneels during a church service, praying. She wears large straw hat. LAURA (V.O., CONT’D) But as a Christian my heart goes out to those people. I just hope they realize that all the time they spent attacking others would have been better improving their overweight, amateurish, whoring lives. Laura makes the SIGN OF THE CROSS and sits back down in t pew. EXT. JOHNSON COUNTY MOOSE LODGE — DAY Nancy pulls up her Taurus to the front of the Moose Lodge Laura is already there, holding a box of SUPPLIES, pacing Nancy looks to her watch. Laura is WAY early.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (to herself) Jesus, Laura. Nancy takes a deep breath. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: 48 INT. JOHNSON COUNTY MOOSE LODGE — SAME A room, about the size of a small high school gym. Four identical glass walled COOLERS have been placed in the room, each containing giant, identical HUNKS OF BUTTER. Taped to the glass of each cooler is a homemade sign: ‘Laura,’ ‘Carol Ann,’ ‘Destiny,’ and ‘Brooke.’ INSERT TITLE CARD — THREE DAYS UNTIL ‘TROWELS DOWN’ CAROL ANN — stares at the massive hunk of butter. She’s trying so har to be an artist but it’s just not coming. She makes a CUT pauses, then stops: this is hard! She sits down on the floor and eats a Twinkie. DESTINY — is carving away. She’s cut the top half of the hunk off a placed it on its side. We can barely make it out at this stage, but it looks like it’s going to be a TRAIN. BROOKE'S COOLER — is empty. She probably forgot. LAURA'S COOLER — Laura stares at the hunk of butter, determined. LATER — CAROL ANN — has made a few cuts. She seems proud and honestly, we hav no idea why since her hunk of butter now looks like a mangled hunk of butter. DESTINY — is trucking away. Her TRAIN is really starting to materialize now. It has three cars, and she’s even manage to capture the smoke from the engine’s smokestack. As she works on the second hunk of butter, she looks up — Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: LAURA-
dialogues.text: arms folded, STARES at Destiny from outside. It’s chillin DESTINY — catches Laura staring at her and smiles. Laura looks at her, cold and unflinching, and then walks away. INSERT TITLE CARD — TWO DAYS UNTIL ‘TROWELS DOWN’ MAIN ROOM — Along with the four coolers, about 20 or so VISITORS have come to check out the progress. Ethan and Jill are there, and wave to Destiny.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: (whispering) This is weird.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Just be supportive. Jill looks to him: but it’s weird. DESTINY — Her train is fully complete now. It’s amazing. Three cars with life-life detail. She’s hard at work at the second part of her piece. It’s a human figure of some sort.. we can’t quite tell yet. CAROL ANN — We can MAYBE see what she’s going for now: THREE KITTENS a bucket or a maybe a Hickory Farms gift basket? Regardless, it looks like shit and Carol Ann knows it. It actually kind of heartbreaking. BROOKE'S COOLER — is still empty. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: 50 CAROL ANN — exasperated, gets up, pops open a Diet Snapple, and walks over to LAURA’S COOLER — Laura’s moving along nicely. We can see she’s completed a few FIGURES, SEATED IN CHAIRS. As much as we hate to admi it. She’s doing a great job. Carol Ann raps on the glass. Laura opens the cooler door.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Carol Ann.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANN
dialogues.text: Oh, I’m sorry. You must be hard at work in there creating your little masterpiece. Mine..2 I don’t know. I mean, I thought it would work out but — this is hard, Laura.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: How’s the girl’s look? What’s her name? Tuniesha?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANN
dialogues.text: Destiny.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s right. Pretty name. I mean, she’s only 12. I wish her luck.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANN
dialogues.text: She’s actually really good. You should see it. Laura takes her best I can’t be bothered face and steps o of her cooler. OUTSIDE DESTINY’S COOLER — Laura sours. Destiny is finished and her sculpture is AMAZING. What’s worse for Laura, we see Destiny’s full vision now: THE UNDERGROUND RAILROAD. The train is the same, but now we s the figure she was carving is HARRIET TUBMAN. The wind fr Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: 51 the passing train blows gently at her scarf and her face a creamy mixture of hope and pain.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So she decided to play the race card? Figures. I suppose if you can’t compete on talent alone...

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (to Carol Ann) Well, good for her.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANN
dialogues.text: It's amazing, isn’t it? I mean, that’s almost as good as anything Bob’s ever done. Laura shoots Carol Ann a look and storms back to her cooler. LATER — A group of WEBELOS (young boy scouts) has come on an outi to check out the progress. Hayden (he kindly gave Destiny his pencil at school) is there, too. They’re taken in by Destiny's sculpture, until - A pair of CLEAR HIGH HEELS struts on the tiled floor. Brooke has entered the building. Carol Ann spots her. Brooke spots her back and FLICKS her tongue sexually. Carol Ann is mortified. LATER —

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE BROOKE'S COOLER
dialogues.text: The Webelos press their faces up against the glass of Brooke’s cooler. Judging from her tank top, it sure is co in there. Brooke stares at her hunk of butter, picks up a trowel, a then makes a few cuts. She then shapes the thing a bit wi her hands. And as quick as she came, she’s DONE. (we don’t see her work yet.) Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  52 MAIN ROOM —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brooke exits passing Carol Ann.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Cute shoes. Carol Ann is flummoxed but smiles anyway. Brooke leaves, lighting up a cigarette. MAIN HALL — A crowd has formed around Nancy, who taps into a microphone. There is an excitement in the air.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Contestants - Nancy looks at her STOPWATCH.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY AND CROWD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: 53 EXT. MOOSE LODGE — NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The parking lot is packed. This is a BIG DEAL for Johnson County. INT. MOOSE LODGE — SAME A crowd mills about behind the now roped-off coolers. Eac contestant stands in front of their respective sculpture. Laura across from Destiny; Carol Ann across from Brooke. We can now see Laura’s sculpture: a happy family, seated a_dinner table, praying. And you know what, it’s also AMAZING. Way better than anyone else’s. Laura has got this locked up. Laura catches Destiny’s eye and smiles. Destiny ignores her. She’s all steel nerves. LATER — Nancy taps on a MICROPHONE and stands on a milk crate.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Ladies and Gentleman, welcome to the Johnson County Run-Off of the State Mastery in Butter Competition. The crowd CLAPS. Ethan and Jill, as well as some other students and faculty from Country Day are there to suppor Destiny.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I'd like to introduce our esteemed panel of judges. From left to right, Betsy Lou Holt, our reigning Miss Dairy. More claps. BETSY LOU HOLT smiles. She's pretty and clear likes her dairy. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  54

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Next we have the Mayor of Iowa City, Bill Olberweis. And finally, wife of State Head Judge Orval Anderson, Mrs- Helen Anderson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd cheers. Laura looks at Helen and smiles sweetly I hate you.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Now, we’re going to let each contestant say a few words about their work before the judges begin deliberating. We’ll go in order, left to right. Carol Ann Stevenson? Claps. Carol Ann, a nervous wreck, steps up onto the milk crate.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANN
dialogues.text: Oh God, I don’t know what to say! There's so many people here! Whew! I just really love kittens? Especially when they get tangled in a blanket which I didn’t do because that would be so hard to carve so I put them in a basket instead. I hope that's okay? Thank you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carol Ann steps down. No one really knows what to do so a few polite people clap.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Carol Ann. (BEAT, disdainful) Brooke? Brooke walks up to the microphone. Instead of being dress like her usual skank, she's all cleaned up, wearing a pretty, modest Laura Ashley dress, a nice shawl and dewy make-up. She looks right at Laura.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Many of you know that I ama former stripper, many times even taking my job further and engaging in sexual acts for money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd GASPS. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 55 BROOKE (CONT’D) I have lived a life of sin. But recently I realized that all the men, all the lap dances, all the money - it was merely a replacement for the love I never received from my abusive father. I went from man to man to man, always looking, always searching. And one day, after I was nearly beaten to death by a customer, who, incidentally, I have reason to believe was Muslim, I stumbled into another house, a big welcoming house, and met another man. (dramatic, leaning into microphone) And that man was Jesus Christ. The crowd nods, especially the judges. They’re touched. Brooke stares down Laura: I told you it was on, hussy.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I think my work speaks for itself. Brooke moves aside, revealing her crappy sculpture. It pretty much looks like a stick-drawing drawn on a hunk of butter. There are two eyes and a mouth and a giant “A” drawn on the figure’s chest in red lipstick.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I call it My Scarlet Letter and it’s inspired by a movie starring Demi Moore. Thank you and God bless you. (shouting) Butter saves! Cheers! The crowd is moved. Many people nod their heads. Brooke steps down. Laura cannot believe people are buying this shit. Brooke looks over to Bob and mouths the words: 600 dollar

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well thank you, Brooke. That was very inspirational. Destiny? Now Destiny takes the podium and pulls out a few rumpled note cards. She’s really shy and nervous, but the crowd sees that’s she’s only 12 and lets out a big adorable sig Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd The crowd 56

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Hi. GUSHES. Laura rolls her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: (poised) My name is Destiny. My last name is either Washington or Wilson. The reason I’m not sure is because the state of Iowa is not sure. You see, I am, and have been, a foster child. I have been shuttled from home to to home. And while some of my experiences have been negative, most have been overwhelmingly positive. I have seen the great people of Iowa, from Des Moines to Winnemucca County and I know this to be true: Iowans are the greatest people ever to walk the face of the Earth! CHEERS. Destiny puts down her note cards. She’s just getting warmed up. The crowd

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So why then, can a 12-year-old black girl with no family history, no money and no connections, stand before you and dare to think she can win this competition? (BEAT, leaning forward, dramatic) Because I dare to dream. is RAPT. DESTINY (CONT’D) (increasingly more animated) It is that same daring that drove the Pilgrims across the vast, dark oceans to America. Why did they risk it? (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because they dared to dream. Seriously, people are hanging off every word. Some people have started to tear up. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd 57

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And it is the daring of a man named Abraham Lincoln, who moved from a log house to the White House and risked both houses to keep this great nation together. Why? (BEAT, the crowd repeats with her!) Because he dared to dream. is on their feet, standing in elation!

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (pointing to her sculpture) And it was the gumption of a poor black woman, who risked life and limb, partnering with white and black alike, to bring my ancestors to freedom on the underground railroad. Why?

dialogues.speaker: DEATINY AND THE CROWD
dialogues.text: Because she dared to dream!

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: Because she dared to dream!

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: I can’t hear you!

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: And what are we gonna’ do from now on, Iowa?! We’re gonna’ —

dialogues.speaker: DARE TO DREAM
dialogues.text: Destiny smiles. Her work here is done.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Thank you very much. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: 58 The crowd GOES WILD, LETTING OUT ONE BIG MASSIVE CATHARTI APPLAUSE. There’s no way they couldn’t. Men are crying, a are clapping — and all for little Destiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON LAURA — She’s toast and she knows it. Laura is shaken.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: And last, but certainly not least, Laura Pickler! Laura, come on up. Laura is caught off guard, but stumbles up to the milk crate. It does not look good for her now.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (nervous and horrible) Family. When I think about butter I think of family. Why? Because like the thread of a grandmother’s quilt, butter is the centerpiece of the family dinner and family in turn, is the thread that holds our great country together. Without butter, there is no family, and without family, there is no United states of America. Thank you. A few polite claps. Laura, mortified, walks back to her spot.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (whispering) You did great.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I was terrible. Laura is fuming. Nancy returns to the milk crate.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Thank you, all four of you. We have coffee and donut holes in the back for everyone while the judges deliberate. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: (whispering to Laura) I’ve been through this before. Just relax. It’s in someone else’s hands now. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (possessed) It’s never in someone else’s hands. And then —

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (loud) Excuse me — Laura stands up before the panel of judges. She knows thi is her last stand and Laura Pickler is not going down without a fight. She walks over to the milk crate.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd like to say a few more words if I may? The judges look to each other then give her the go-ahead.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: you know, this really hard. And then she begins to cry. We don't quite know if its heartfelt cry or an ‘I’m going to lose’ cry- LAURA (CONT’D) Before you cast what may be the most important vote of your lifetime, I’d like to remind you what this contest is about. It is about ‘excellence in butter.’ And from what I’ve seen in recent days, my faith in this panel’s commitment to excellence has been challenged. Unless I’m mistaken some people seem to think this competition is about who is the most disadvantaged, who’s had the hardest life. Who’s had to overcome the most to get here. The judges and the crowd seem skeptical. LAURA (CONT’D)) You know, this is exactly why I stopped watching my American Idol. Every year the best singer gets up there and every year she gets knocked down by some ghetto queen with a baby and mug shot. Well I’m sorry that I was born white and tall and Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: pretty. I’m sorry I don’t sit in front of the TV all day inhaling pork rinds and soiling myself. Laura glances over to Carol Ann who chows down on a bag o Funyons. LAURA (CONT‘D) And I am sorry that I didn’t spend 15 years of my life sucking every cock that flew in front of my face, only to throw on a cheap church dress and claim to find God. Laura looks to Brooke. The crowd is stunned. LAURA (CONT’D) And I’m sorry my ancestors weren’t running around naked in a field of cotton singing Amazing Grace. Laura looks to Destiny.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I guess I’m most sorry I spent all my life working hard and doing the right thing. Because that’s what I thought this competition was about. And I just hope when you vote, you remember that. Laura steps down. And guess what? She’s got them back. A few people in the crowd are not having it, but for the most part, folks are nodding their heads, especially the judges. She looks to Brooke and Destiny: now who’s on top LATER — The crowd mills about, enjoying their donut holes and congratulating Laura on her impending win. Nancy enters and pulls Laura aside.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Can I speak with you privately?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Of course. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: 61 INT. WOMEN'S RESTROOM — SAME Nancy and Laura talk.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: - there are concerns?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes. Some of the judges are of the opinion that perhaps your work is not entirely your own.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: And you defended me, right?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, I — I’m impartial —

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I assume they showed you proof? Where is it? I want to see it.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, it was just a sense that some of them-

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: It was that Miss Dairy heifer, wasn’t it? Or that Helen. You know she has a history of lying, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No, I wasn’t aware of that. Laura moves closer to Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: The work is mine. And unless they can prove otherwise, I suggest you march right back in there and tell them to vote for the best. You know Ned Eaton will be representing Winnebago County again, don’t you? Who do you think will be strongest up against him? The stripper or Little Miss ‘I don’t know nothin’’bout birthin’ no babies?’ Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 62 Nancy sighs.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I’m the best and if I don’t win I will go to The Register and expose this panel like there’s no tomorrow. Do you think you can handle a media shit-storm, Nancy? Nancy holds her tongue.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I’1l see what I can do. Nancy exits. Laura paces. INT. MOOSE LODGE — MAIN HALL — LATER The donut holes are all gone. Nancy approaches the microphone with the Judges behind he She seems unduly nervous for an event such as this.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: If I may have your attention. We have a decision. It’s almost like she’s reading a verdict. The crowd gathe ‘round. Laura puts on her best fake-smile. NANCY (CONT’D) (looking at a note card) In fourth place, we have Carol Ann Stevenson! Polite claps, but Carol Ann is over the moon!

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh my God! I won something! Carol Ann races up and takes her fourth place ribbon.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Congrats Carol Ann. (sour) And in third place, we have Brooke Sosnowski. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 63 Brooke walks up and snatches her ribbon from Nancy's hand No one really claps, but some people feel sorry for her. NANCY (CONT’D) We hope you continue on your path towards righteousness.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Oh, I will. Brooke smiles to the crowd. On her way out, Brooke spots Destiny.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (whispering, looking to Laura) I know you're only, like, 12 and shit but listen up: you beat that skangy ass cunt and you beat her hard. Destiny nods. Brooke You're a good girl. Brooke pats her on the shoulder and gets the hell out.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Now, if we could have Laura Pickler and Destiny come on up here. Both walk up. Nancy holds one blue and one red ribbon in her hand. NANCY (CONT’D) Representing Johnson County in the Iowa State Fair Mastery in Butter Competition this year will be — Laura STARES at Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Destiny! The crowd cheers! SLOW MOTION; LAURA’S P.O.V.: Nancy pins the BLUE RIBBON o Destiny’s shirt. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: She looks to Bob, then Nancy, then Helen — all the people that have forsaken her as they rush to congratulate Desti - leaving Laura alone with just her pained, pained smile. INT. COUNTRY DAY SCHOOL — DAY Destiny walks down the hall, this time wearing a uniform just like everyone else. Everyone congratulates her as sh passes.

dialogues.speaker: KIDS
dialogues.text: Way to go Destiny! Congrats! You're the best. Destiny soaks it in.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I guess it was wrong of me to say that all white people are weird. That’s not true at all. Most white people are really awesome! EXT. HIGHWAY 70 — LATER Laura careens her Suburban down the highway. The whole family is buckled up. Laura is tense.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Fuck that little nigger bitch!

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: Mom! You can’t say that word.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Kaitlen, your mother’s upset.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: No. She’s right, I shouldn’t say that. (BEAT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck that little black bitch. Oh, she knew she was good all along. She hustled us. She’s a hustler. And then pulling out that Martin Luther King bullshit. Please. How are normal people supposed to compete with that? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  65

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: Mom. What’s your problem? It’s just some stupid contest.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You know, Nancy approached me during break and expressed a concern that perhaps Destiny did not carve that all on her own. And, of course, I defended her. I’m starting to regret my kindness.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: God. I can’t wait ‘til I’m 18 so I can get out of this stupid family. Laura drives faster.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: And where will you live? How will you pay your bills. It’s not like you’re getting into any college with your grades.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: Girls. It’s been a long day. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll be a stripper, like Dad’s friend. Laura is floored. Bob’s not too happy either. Kaitlen seems pleased: she knows to hit where it hurts. But then again, so does her mom.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: With your body? Well, I wish you luck. Laura pulls into the driveway and stops the car. Kaitlen, mess of anger and tears, runs out.

dialogues.speaker: GOD
dialogues.text: Kaitlen races inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: LAURA

THE EMMIT HOUSE — LATER A CAKE - It’s white with blue icing that reads ‘Congratulations Destiny!’ Two SPARKLERS are stuck in the icing and light up the dining room. Ethan pours everyone a glass of sparkling apple juice and toasts.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: To Destiny!

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: To Destiny! Ethan, Jill, Destiny and Hayden chow down on cake and natural soda. Hayden hands Destiny a GIFT, wrapped in newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: HAYDEN

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Thank you. I like it. Hayden smiles. Destiny shovels a big piece of cake in her mouth when SUDDENLY they hear

dialogues.speaker: TIRES SCREECHING
dialogues.text: EXT. EMMIT HOME — MOMENTS LATER Jill, Ethan, Destiny and Hayden stand in the yard, starin at the house. They’re looking at SOMETHING:

dialogues.speaker: HAYDEN
dialogues.text: (reading) Http colon mark double backslash www dot youtube dot com backslash watch question mark v equal sign 90 DqOq3lssg (BEAT) Is that a gang? REVERSE ANGLE: An ENTIRE WEBSITE URL is spray painted on their garage door. They’ve been vandalized in perhaps the dumbest way ever. Jill races inside, pissed. INT. EMMIT FAMILY HOME — LATER The family is huddled over Ethan’s Macbook watching a video: INSERT: a YouTube clip titled “PETA PROTEST — MIDWAY DAIR — 1991.” Several college students stand in front of a dairy facility. In the video, we see three cow stuffed animals hanging from nooses. Some students throw fake blood on th stuffed animals. And then we see a woman holding a megaphone move into frame. It’s Jill from 1991: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: (to Jill) That's you. Jill looks to Ethan: you have GOT to be kidding me. EXT. BOLTON FORD — LOT — LATER Laura stands by her damaged minivan (from when she slamme it in the strip club parking lot.) In the distance, amongst rows of new Explorers and Ranger a handsome man approaches - BOYD BOLTON.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Boyd! Boyd removes his cap. He’s thrilled to see his old flame.

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: Laura Pickler.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Bob wrecked our minivan.

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: I see that. What did he do?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: He slammed into something he shouldn’t have slammed into.

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: Oh, boy, that’s too bad. Well if you want we can have this fixed for you right away. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That would be excellent.

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: Gosh. Laura, you know, you look great. I mean, even better than you did in high school. Most women go the other way.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Oh, and how is your wife?

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: Tiffany? Oh, well she’s fine I guess.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: How nice. Laura smiles. That’s all she needs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill, with some turpentine and a scrub brush, tries to remove the spray paint from the garage door. Ethan approaches.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I‘1l take over.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: It’s not coming off. Jill removes her rubber gloves and wipes her brow.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I don’t know if I can do this, Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I said I'll take over.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: That’s not what I mean. Ethan gets closer. He sees she’s upset.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: The cooking. The laundry. And I have to watch my mouth. And the butter thing? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: c'mon, it’s weird. A grown woman vandalized our home. I mean, honestly. These people are nuts.(BEAT) I’m just not meant to be a mom. I can’t do it. She’s a sweet kid but, I don’t know. Jill walks away. But we pull back to reveal Destiny, looking on from the front porch. She heard the whole thin INT. PICKLER HOME — KAITLEN’S ROOM — SAME Kaitlen sits on her bed smoking a bowl. She coughs, and then blows the smoke into a blow tube (a toilet paper tub with dryer sheets stuffed in the end.) EXT. PICKLER FAMILY HOME — SIDE VIEW — LATER Brooke, dressed in head-to-toe black, picks up a rock and tosses at an illuminated upstairs window. INSIDE — The ROCK hits the window.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: Whoa. Another ROCK. Kaitlen gets up and looks out the window. She sees BROOKE —

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Hey. Can I come up? Kaitlen nods.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: Meet me around back. KAITLEN’S ROOM — ON TV: a WOMAN sells the “Snuzzler” (a support for your newborn’s head) on the Home Shopping Network. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  71

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: (stoned, to Brooke) Don’t you think its weird that babies can’t hold up their heads on their own? I mean think about how fucked up that is? Its like you shouldn't be allowed to exist or something if you cant hold up your own head by yourself. Whatever. I think everyone should be forced to have abortions anyways. I mean, think about it. Is a baby better off dead or in the suburbs? At least you feel no pain when you’re vacuumed out of some cooter but in the suburbs you’re forced to live with some stupid family, with stupid people that call you fat when you are not fat at all and then you have to deal with stupid boys like Rob Ackerman who don’t call you back even though you blow them in the backseat of their Kia’s. (BEAT) God, I hate people and I can’t wait ‘til everyone dies from Global Warming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kaitlen takes another hit.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Right. You don’t know where your dad keeps his money, do you?

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: Why? Does he owe you money? (intrigued) Like for sex. Kaitlen smiles at Brooke. Like, really smiles at Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: He just owes me money, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: Your hair is so cool.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Thank you. So, the cash would-

dialogues.speaker: KAILTEN
dialogues.text: I’ve never met anyone like you. You’re so alternative.

dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: -would be in one of his drawers or something, right?

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Do you want to play Truth or Dare? The look on Brooke’s face says it all. STAIRWELL — Laura, fully dressed, TIPTOES down the stairs. She reache the front door, notices Bob asleep, and slowly cracks ope to door. OUTSIDE — Laura gets into her Suburban.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is quiet. Laura’s Suburban pulls up. INT. BOLTON FORD — LATER We track through the dark and empty showroom. Past that, see a LIGHT on in a back office. And then we hear SEX MOANS. Instead of heading down the hall, we slowly focus in on a LIFESIZE CARDBOARD CUT-OUT of BOYD that reads “Bolton Ford: We’re all about the service.” The moans continue. INT. THE PICKLER FAMILY HOME — KAITLEN’S ROOM - LATER CLOSE ON KAITLEN’S face. He’s got major ‘0’ face. Brooke lifts her head up.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: Don’t stop. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I can’t do this. It’s just not me.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: I can get you that 600 dollars. Brooke considers this.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: It was actually 1200. Kaitlen moves in closer to kiss Brooke.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: You’re so beautiful and different. Brooke is freaked, but tries to play along.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: You’re everything I’ve ever wanted to be and now you’re right here.. in my arms. Kaitlen is so sincere it’s painful. Brooke is dying but s has her priorities. She leans in and kisses Kaitlen. INT. BOLTON FORD — NIGHT Boyd sits inside the yellow Mustang that’s on display in the showroom. Tears are in his eyes. Through the window, we see Laura’s Suburban pull away.

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: Are you there, God? It’s me, Boyd Bolton. I just did a very bad thing. But I guess you already know that. It’s just that — I can’t help myself around her. She’s so beautiful and sophisticated and her hair smells like fancy shampoo and now I just really need your guidance because I don’t think I’1l be able to control myself next time either. Boyd makes the sign of the cross.

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: Amen. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: She's going to love that. Destiny doesn’t seem all that thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Something bothering you?

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Okay. The phone RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (on phone) Hello? Sure, I think we can do that. Ok. Thank you, Nancy. Ethan hangs up and looks at the phone oddly. INT. MOOSE LODGE — COMMUNITY ROOM B — NIGHT A nondescript conference room in the Moose Lodge. Nothing could be more depressing. Ethan and Jill enter, followed by Destiny. Already seated at the table, and staring at them like they’ve just drowned a puppy is Laura, Nancy, Orval, Bob, the three county judges and one BUSINESS MAN. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Destiny. Come in. Have a seat. Destiny sits down.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: What’s going on? The room is silent. Laura is beaming. Nancy motions toward the Business Man.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: This is Martin Caswell- (then, nervous) -from Land O’ Lakes. Laura stands up. She slides over a LAPTOP COMPUTER and presses a button... INSERT: the PETA YouTube clip (the URL Laura ‘allegedly’ spray painted on their garage door.)

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO ROOM-
dialogues.text: Laura shuts the laptop triumphantly. The crowd is stunned

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (looking to Laura) Yeah. We saw it.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, obviously this is an issue for Destiny. Ethan looks to Jill, incredulous.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: This could get out. The Register will have a field day.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: What? Are you kidding me? You're kidding me, right? That was 20 years ago. And it’s me, for crying out loud, Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  76

dialogues.speaker: JILL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: not her. And it’s a protest. People have a right to protest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura smiles, calmly.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well, we just don’t know what kind of thoughts you might be putting into her head.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: I mean she could be using her win here at county to infiltrate state with some sort of anti-butter protest. (to Martin Caswell) And with the media there and everything, I’d say that’s a huge risk for the Land O’ Lakes brand. Martin nods. Bob lowers his head, he’s so embarrassed to a part of this. Ethan and Jill are livid.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN CASWELL
dialogues.text: Obviously we at Land 0’ Lakes share Ms. Pickler’s concerns, however, we will take you at your word that some- thing like this won’t happen at State. You do reject your foster mother’s actions, Destiny, don’t you? Destiny looks to Martin and then to Jill. And then she begins to CRY. She gets up and runs out of the room. Jill gets up but Ethan stops her.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Let me. Ethan follows Destiny. Jill folds her arms: I hope you people are happy. HALLWAY — LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ethan and Destiny sit on plastic chairs. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  77

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Adults can be - they can be unfair sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: I’m scared.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Why? You’re amazing. It’s everyone else that should be scared. They’1l see this dumb thing for what it is and then you'll win this State thing. I mean, did you know how talented you are?

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: I’m scared that you and Miss Jill won’t want me anymore. Ethan kneels down. Her statement is heartbreaking to him.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: It’s happened before.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: I heard Miss Jill. By the garage. Ethan considers this.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Did you know that Jill can’t have babies.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Well, that’s complicated.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Her vagina’s broken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  78

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I guess you could say that. But the adoption people would ask as over and over ‘are you sure you don’t want a baby? We can get you a baby. You both have good jobs, you have a nice house, we can get you a baby. And we made up this whole thing in our heads that, like, we wanted an older child because they always get overlooked and we'd be doing so much to help the world and society and everything. but the truth is that we're scared to have a baby.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: why?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Destiny pats him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: It’s okay to be scared, I guess

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Destiny stands up.

dialogues.speaker: MEETING ROOM-
dialogues.text: Jill is about to blow up the whole thing is so retarded. Destiny and Ethan enter.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN CASWELL
dialogues.text: So. Destiny. Do you denounce your foster mom's actions?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: (to Destiny) Denounce means ‘reject.’

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: I know what it means and no, Sir. I won't. I personally wouldn't do something like that because it’s not my thing, but I can’t denounce her. She can say and do what she wants and that’s nobody's business but hers. (BEAT) And she’s my mom and I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: love her. Jill and Ethan cannot believe what they just heard. It is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN CASWELL
dialogues.text: (moved) That was very well said, Destiny. Now Laura is pissed again. Her plan didn’t work.

dialogues.speaker: MARTIN CASWELL
dialogues.text: (to Nancy) The company has no problem being represented by Destiny. Martin begins to stand up but Laura cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Boyd? Can you come in here, please? Boyd Bolton enters and removes his hat. Everyone kind of looks around: what?

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Boyd. Tell everyone what you told me. Boyd looks around. He seems nervous.

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: On the evening of the 15“, Mr. Ethan Emmit approached me and knowing I have superior skills in the art of sculpting butter asked if I could help his daughter Destiny with her entry for the Johnson County Mastery in Butter contest. I said no at first but then he offered me five hundred dollars so I snuck in every night and carved her sculpture for her. It was only after I saw how distraught the innocent Laura Pickler was that I felt the need to come forward. I can no longer bear to live with this horrible blight on my conscience. Thank you. Boyd looks up to Laura, proud. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Well. I think that speaks for itself.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: I’ve never met this dude in my life.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Seriously. This is a joke. We’re leaving. (looking to the crowd) I mean, c’mon. Some of them look away. They’re actually buying this crap

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: You guys saw her carve it with your own eyes. I can’t believe I’m even arguing this.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: Mr. Bolton. You swear this is the truth? Boyd, unsure, looks to Laura. She nods for him to say
yes.

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: You are responsible for Destiny’s work?

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: This Destiny. Right here? Boyd looks to Destiny. It registers that he’s throwing a year old girl under the bus. He looks to Laura. Her look says it all.

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: I don’t know. Seems fishy. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 81 Laura stands up.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: May I make a suggestion? The judges give her the go ahead. Jill and Ethan are abou to rip her head off.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: As it’s clear that Destiny’s win is in question, I think the only fair solution would be to have a rematch. Me vs. Destiny. This Saturday. Right here at the Moose lodge. Jill stands up.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Absolutely not. Destiny won on her own, fair and square. What’s wrong with you people? I can’t believe you will let this two-bit trophy wife- This sets off a shouting match of accusations and anger amidst everyone except Destiny. As it escalates, Destiny quietly stands up.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: I’1l do it. The crowd quiets down.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Destiny-

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: I’m in. Destiny reaches across the table and shakes Laura’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: 8 hour carve time, all out in the open. Officials present every minute. Pre- approved tools. No verbal contact with the audience. No help. Deal? Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Destiny. You do not have to agree to this.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: I already beat her once. I don’t have a problem doing it again. Destiny gets up, poised and confident, and exits. Jill an Ethan follow. Bob looks to Laura, embarrassed for her. EXT. MOOSE LODGE — HALLWAY — LATER Folks have gone mostly, but Boyd races up to Laura. He’s distraught.

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: Laura.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Boyd.

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: She’s only 12!

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: (whispering) And black! Laura looks at Boyd: you’re useless to me now.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Thank you for your help, Boyd.

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: But- Laura walks away. BOYD (CONT’D) Wait? When can I see you again? Laura exits. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.text: 83 BOYD (CONT’D) Laura? Laura? I need to see you. Boyd’s got it bad. INT. VOLVO — NIGHT Jill drives, with Ethan in the passenger seat. Destiny is in the back.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Can you believe that bitch?

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: gill.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. (to Destiny) You know you can’t say ‘bitch,’ right? Destiny chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Eh. Just her whole thing — the hair, the dress, that grin — I mean, give me a break.

dialogues.text: Destiny, We still have time to go back there and tell them we don’t want to do this- Jill pulls into their driveway and abruptly stops the car She looks to Ethan.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Are you kidding me? Destiny is going to tear that witch apart, aren’t you Destiny? Destiny smiles. Jill is officially on board. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
