dialogues.text: Yes, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Good girl. (BEAT) Now let’s go. We have a lot of prep work to do. The ‘new family’ exits the Volvo and heads inside. INT. PICKLER FAMILY HOME — BASEMENT — NIGHT Laura stands before an un-carved massive block of butter their basement, in-home butter carving unit. Bob looks on

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: This isn’t gonna’ work, Laura. You’re gonna’ need an understructure for something that grand.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: Then I‘11 do an understructure. I’m not afraid of hard work.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: You can’t learn all these things, Laura. It’s hard work, sure, but there’s also an art to it. It takes years, and even then, some people just can’t be an artist.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: An artist? Thomas Kinkaide is an artist. Celine Dion is an artist. You carve butter, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: BOB
dialogues.text: It’s not just hard work, Laura. That’s all I’m saying.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: That's why I have a back-up plan. Bob looks at her: what’s that’s supposed to mean? INT. THE EMMIT HOME — LIVING ROOM — SAME Destiny stands in front of the TV, as if she’s about to give a presentation. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Option A... Destiny pulls out a yellow, play-doh mock up of a prospective sculpture: A man with an afro smacks a woman across the face.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Ike and Tina Turner? Seated on the couch are Ethan, Jill and Hayden. The all shake their heads: NO, NO, NO. LIVING ROOM — LATER Destiny shows the group another mock up: A woman with her head in a guillotine.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: I call it ‘Let them Eat Cake.” It moves. The guillotine falls down and slices off Marie Antoinette Play-doh head.

dialogues.speaker: HAYDEN
dialogues.text: Cool. Ethan and Jill look to Destiny: No. LATER — Everyone is tired and exasperated. The doorbell RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: I’ll get it. The all jump up. AT DOOR — Carol Ann Stevenson stands outside holding a Tupperware container. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANN
dialogues.text: I just wanted to apologize for supporting that horrible woman and I came to help out in anyway that I can. Destiny smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANN
dialogues.text: And I made my famous Peeps Lemon Meringue Piel! Carol Ann removes the lid of her Tupperware dish, reveali a pie, topped with melted, year-old Easter Peeps. The reaction is not good. LIVING ROOM — LATER On the couch: Jill, Hayden, Ethan and Carol Ann. They all shake their heads: NO! (we don’t even see Destiny this time.) LIVING ROOM — LATER Same folks on the couch but this time they nod.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: That’s it! Everyone seems to be in agreement (we don’t see her mock- up-) EXT. TATE HIGH SCHOOL — TRACK FIELD — DAY A group of BAND GEEKS practice in the background. Brooke’ car is parked behind the bleachers. INT. BROOKE’S CAR — SAME KAITLEN is in the passenger seat. She’s in a state of pos coital bliss.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: We should get an apartment together. We could move to Des Moines. Brooke rolls her eyes. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: So you got the 1200 dollars, right?

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: (blissful) Or maybe Chicago. I heard you can be who you really are in the big city. Brooke is dying a thousand deaths.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You’re probably gonna’ be late for practice. Kaitlen leans back, blissful.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: Screw The Man. I could stay with you forever. Brooke reaches over and opens Kaitlen’s door. She motions for her to get out.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: Ok. Call me, okay.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: The money?

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: Oh. Kaitlen hands Brooke the wad of cash.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: Call me. We could maybe go furniture shopping later or something, okay? Brooke’s face says it all as she peels out. EXT. COUNTRY DAY SCHOOL — SAME Brooke pulls out front just as the kids are getting out f the day. She spots Destiny and honks her horn.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Hey girl. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: Hop in. I got something for you. Destiny smiles and hops in. INT. WILLIAMS-SONOMA KITCHEN STORE — LATER CLOSE-ON: a set of VERY EXPENSIVE CHEF’S KNIVES laid out black velvet. They SPARKLE under the store’s lights. We pull back to reveal a CLERK showing Brooke and Destiny the showroom quality knives in a Williams-Sonoma store (NOTE: yes, there is one in Iowa.)

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: (to Clerk) Can you leave us alone for a second? The Clerk nods and walks away. Brooke bends down and look Destiny in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You see that store over there? Destiny looks across the mall to VICTORIA'S SECRET. BROOKE (CONT’D) (intense) That's called Victoria’s Secret and with this 1200 dollars I could buy work-clothes like you’ve never seen.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Where do you work? Brooke pauses.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: A bank. Brooke Picks up the LONGEST KNIFE and lays it in Destiny’ hands, like one Samurai to another. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  89 BROOKE (CONT’D) (intense) My point is that I am willing to sacrifice 1200 dollars worth of totally cute outfits so that you may enact God’s will here on Earth. And you do that by kicking the shit out of Laura Pickler’s pasty white ass so hard that she and her hapless husband will never be able to wreak havoc on the poor innocent citizens of Johnson County again. We cool?

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Thank you. Brooke looks across the mall one last time, toward a supe hot g-string. She’s pained, but pushes through.

dialogues.speaker: BROOKE
dialogues.text: You're welcome. Brooke stands up, a new woman. LATER —

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brooke’s bug leaves the mall parking lot, passing a YELLO MUSTANG. The Mustang parks outside Williams Sonoma. INT. VOLVO — THE NEXT DAY Ethan and Destiny drive home from school.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Tomorrow’s the big day. Destiny looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: If you don’t mind, I need to be alone with my thoughts right now. Ethan looks to her: well, okay then. He pulls into the driveway. A_ government car with the State Seal (we remem it as the car that picked up Destiny from her various foster homes earlier,) is taking his spot. Ethan furrows his brow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 INT. EMMIT HOME — KITCHEN — SAME Jill sits at the kitchen table with a WOMAN in a beige suit. She stands up when Ethan and Destiny enter. Jill seems distraught.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (shaking Ethan’s hand) Danielle Mattingly. Iowa Department of Human Services. Have a seat. Ethan sits down. Danielle looks to Destiny.

dialogues.speaker: DANIELLE
dialogues.text: (sweet ) Hi Destiny. (to Ethan) It might be best if we had this discussion alone, just grown ups. Destiny says nothing, but takes a seat anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: (uncharacteristically serious) Destiny, you should go to your room.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: She can stay. Destiny looks to Jill. Jill takes a deep breath and then nods.

dialogues.speaker: DANIELLE
dialogues.text: So, as I was explaining to Jill, we at the DHS believe we have located Destiny’s biological mother.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: When? Where? How do we know she’s legit?

dialogues.speaker: DANIELLE
dialogues.text: Our department fully vets claims such as these. We believe Mrs. Washington is Destiny’s biological mother. Danielle looks away. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  91

dialogues.speaker: DANIELLE
dialogues.text: Actually, was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jill takes Destiny’s hand. Jill is holding back tears. Destiny is unmoved.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: DANIELLE
dialogues.text: I really think this conversation should just be the adults-

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: She can handle it. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: DANIELLE
dialogues.text: From what we can surmise, on the night of - Jill cuts her off.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Destiny. Your mother was a wonderful woman who fell on hard times. She was not capable of caring for you but she loved you very much nonetheless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Destiny is emotionless, at least on the surface.

dialogues.speaker: DANIELLE
dialogues.text: This was her only salvageable possession. Danielle pulls out a small, tattered PHOTOGRAPH, of a wom lying in a hospital bed cradling a newborn. She slides it over to Destiny.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: She’s pretty.

dialogues.speaker: DANIELLE
dialogues.text: Yes, she is.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Can I keep it? Danielle nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: I might need it tomorrow. Destiny stands up and heads to her room. INT. EMMIT HOME — DESTINY’S ROOM — NIGHT The lights are low in Destiny’s bedroom — almost a glow. Destiny sits in front of her mirror. The photograph of he and her mother is wedged in between the glass and the frame. Destiny folds her hands as if she’s praying.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: (closing her eyes tight) Hi Mom. It’s me, Destiny. Your daughter. We probably haven’t seen each other since I was a baby. I don’t remember you at all but now that the lady gave me your picture I wish I did. I’m not sure what you were doing all these years but now that you’ve gone to heaven I just want you to know that I forgive you for leaving me. I don’t really understand it that much but I still forgive you. Destiny stands up, then quickly kneels back down.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: Oh, and if you’re not doing anything tomorrow in heaven, I’m fixin’ to kick this mean lady’s ass in the butter competition so come check it out if you can. Okay. Bye. Destiny gets up and hops into bed. EXT. JOHNSON COUNTY MOOSE LODGE — THE NEXT DAY INSERT TITLE CARD: “Re-Match” The parking lot is PACKED. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 93 INT. MOOSE LODGE — SAME Two coolers face each other. Each with identical slabs of butter. They’re roped off which is a good thing because t room is filled with ONLOOKERS. Destiny, holding the KNIFE SET Brooke bestowed upon her, faces Laura. Laura tries to psych her out with one of her patented smiles, but Destiny is not having it: she’s soli Nancy stands on a crate between then and BLOWS A WHISTLE: It’s on. DESTINY'S COOLER — Destiny unfolds the velvet knife set on the floor. She looks up and spots Brooke, who smiles. Destiny pulls out the longest, shiniest knife and holds i in the light. LAURA’S COOLER — Laura flips through a yellow legal pad filled with detail notes. She seems confused, then she spots Destiny’s shiny knife: shit! CROWD — Even more onlookers file in. From this POV, we can see Destiny has already begun carving her piece. We can’t tel what it is yet. Laura is still frantically flipping through her papers. LATER — Even more people have come to check out the competition. DESTINY’S COOLER — Her piece is moving along. We can make out a figure.. tha about it. LAURA’S COOLER — Laura is moving along too. It kind of looks like a car. Maybe a convertible. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: MAIN ROOM -
dialogues.text: Hayden darts his eyes between both coolers. He's practically about to explode with drama. He races outside. LATER — MAIN ROOM — Carol Ann Stevenson, holding what looks to be a bowl of possibly Jell-o, pounds on the glass and waves.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL ANN
dialogues.text: (shouting) I made you my famous ham, marshmallow Jell-o casserole! Destiny, ever polite, smiles. LAURA'S COOLER — Laura makes a wrong cut. A hunk of butter falls to the floor. She picks it up, livid. She then spots Bob outside the cooler and gives him the evil eye: this is all your fault. MAIN ROOM — We can now see that more people are crowded around Destiny’s cooler than Laura's. EXT. ICE CREAM PARLOR — SAME A group of KIDS sit on their bicycles and eat drippy ice cream cones. Hayden pulls up on his bike.

dialogues.speaker: HAYDEN
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: KID 1
dialogues.text: Hey. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: HAYDEN
dialogues.text: Butter drama down at the Moose Lodge. Hayden takes off on his bike. The other kids look to each other.. then take off too. EXT. MOOSE LODGE — LATER The parking lot’s been full for a while but now we can se the road leading to the Moose Lodge is bumper to bumper t traffic. Hayden and the kids weave through the traffic on their bikes. INT. MOOSE LODGE — SAME Standing room only. The kids make their way past the beer bellies and make it to — DESTINY’S COOLER — We only see it from the back, but it’s a figure of some sort, with long incredibly detailed hair. Despite the crowd outside, Destiny is all focus. LAURA’S COOLER — Laura’s isn’t that bad. It’s a little clunky, but we can make out a few people in a convertible. She doesn’t seem that pleased with her work. Bob, outside, gives her the ‘thumbs up.’ Laura looks to him, unimpressed. LATER — MAIN HALL — CLOSE ON — a pair of sensible shoes step up onto the milk crate. Nancy sounds her whistle.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Three. Two. One. Trowels down! Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 96 The crowd cheers. Destiny, worked up into an artistic frenzy, drops her knife. She’s done. And she’s done it — it’s amazing. DESTINY’S FINAL SCULPTURE - Is simple but lovely. Like Davinci’s Madonna with Child painting, her piece is a_ new mother cradling her baby. Despite the simple image, the detail is intense. The robe the eyes, the child’s tiny fingers — it’s like nothing th crowd has ever seen. MAIN HALL — The crowd, almost simultaneously, whips their head over t LAURA’S FINAL SCULPTURE — Jackie 0. crawling to the back of the presidential limo, while her husband's head is partially blown off. (from th Zapruder Film) It’s well done, but completely tasteless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAIN HALL — The crowd stares at her sculpture — speechless. Laura, wearing a knock-off pink Chanel suit and a pill-box hat, soon sours — it hits her: They hate it. ON NANCY — She taps into the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming. Please come back tomorrow morning after church where the judges will be viewing these two - (looks to Laura’s) - interesting pieces for the first time and will announce the winner of the Johnson County Mastery in Butter competition! (BEAT) Again. As the crowd files out, we close in on Laura, standing there, next to her fucked-up sculpture in her stupid outfit, clutching her cheap purse - watching all her plan slip away.

dialogues.speaker: FADE OUT
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 97 EXT. MOOSE LODGE — NIGHT The place is dead. A JANITOR exits and locks the door behind him. He drives away. INT MOOSE LODGE — NIGHT It’s dark, illuminated only by a few Exit signs. The FRONT DOOR jiggles a bit. Then a bit HARDER. Finally, it FLIES open. We see a FIGURE. Then FOOTSTEPS. Then the door to Destiny’s cooler CREAKS OPEN. And then, from outside the cooler, all we see is the HOT, BLUE FLAME from a créme brulee torch light up Destiny’s butter art. CLOSE ON the face of the child in Destiny’s sculpture as SLOWLY MELTS AWAY. The flame EXTINGUISHES. INT. MOOSE HALL — MAIN ROOM — THE NEXT DAY INSERT TITLE CARD - “FINAL JUDGING” Destiny enters the hall with Ethan and Jill, dressed in their Sunday best. Up ahead, they spot a crowd, including Hayden, gathered around her piece. Hayden looks to her, distraught. Destiny walks closer, and sees her sculpture in the full light of day: the Mother is in tact, but the baby’s face completely melted off. It’s ruined. Ethan races up to Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We don’t know. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca  98

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sabotage.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: Well, she can have time to fix it, right?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: The judges have already begin their deliberations. The rules indicate that no further adjustments can be made once deliberation commences. The judges mill about the coolers. No telling what they’r thinking.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: c'mon, lady.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: My name is Nancy and those are the rules.

dialogues.speaker: ETHAN
dialogues.text: (finally losing it) You people are ridiculous. You know what? It’s butter! You put it on toast. The government gives it away for free! And newsflash? It’s bad for you! Yeah, I said it. It clogs your arteries and makes you fat and you’re all going to die because of it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd is so offended there are no words. Jill apologetically escorts Ethan out of the Main Hall. He nee a time out. WOMEN’S RESTROOM — Laura stares in the mirror, fixing her hair. If it weren’ Laura, we'd think maybe she was a bit nervous. And then, Destiny enters. Laura eyes her through the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: I just wanted to wish you good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 99 Destiny reaches out her hand. Laura rebuffs her handshake and continues fixing her hair.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: You know this is all I have. Destiny doesn’t know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're young. You have your whole life ahead of you. You can do anything. You won’t understand but this is it for me. This is all I have. Laura, realizes she’s let her guard down, immediately pul it back together and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I hope you’re happy with yourself. Destiny seems shaken.

dialogues.speaker: MAIN HALL-
dialogues.text: Nancy is back up on her milk crate, tapping into the microphone. The judges stand behind her.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: May I have your attention, please? The judges have reached a decision. And in the distance, we see Laura, holding Bob’s hand, ma her way up front. Her hair is perfection, her make-up is flawless and she is ready to accept her crown.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Orval? Orval (the head judge) steps up onto the milk crate.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: In my years judging this competition, I have seen many things. But only twice have I seen true art. The first time was Bob Pickler’s truly brilliant Passion of The Christ with Garth Brooks as Jesus. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 100 ORVAL (CONT’D) And the second time this morning. When I laid my eyes upon a work so tragic, so touching, that it became not just butter carving, but butter art. Laura BEAMS.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: And to be touched yourself, you merely need to look right here, to the sad, melted face of this unloved child. He points to Destiny’s piece.

dialogues.speaker: ORVAL
dialogues.text: Our winner... (looking to Laura) «again, is Destiny Washington! The crowd FLIPS OUT! CHEERS! The crowd swarms our little Destiny, lifting her up in the air, but also.. FROM DESTINY'S P.O.V.: Laura is left all alone. Destiny motions for the crowd to let her down and walks over to Laura. The crowd silences. They’re watching this little girl get into the water with Jaws.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY
dialogues.text: (extending her hand) I wanted to thank you. Laura holds it all in. DESTINY (CONT’D) I‘m a better competitor because of you. Before she can respond, Destiny HUGS Laura. She resists a first — it’s all so foreign to her — but then we see something amazing. There, in the arms of Destiny, Laura’s shell finally cracks. She closes her eyes, and - SMILES. Her first real smile in 20 years.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O)
dialogues.text: Someone once told me a story about a man who, at the old age of 65, found Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O., CONT'D)
dialogues.text: himself depressed and penniless. Destiny and Laura hug. Laura won’t let go. EXT. PICKLER HOME — DRIVEWAY A U-HAUL sits in the driveway. Bob hands a STACK OF PAPER to Laura. He won’t look her in the eye. Carol Ann Stevens waits in the passenger seat of the U-Haul, uncomfortable. LAURA (V.O., CONT’D) But he was an excellent chef. He went from restaurant to restaurant pedaling his recipes, hoping to split the profits. He was rejected not once, not twice, but a thousand and eight times. Laura signs her name on the last paper and hands it to Bo INT. ROSIES II STRIP CLUB — SAME Kaitlen, with short, spiky hair, sits in the back of the club watching Brooke do her act. LAURA (V.O., CONT’D) The old man’s family no longer supported him. A MAN puts a dollar in Brooke’s g-string.

dialogues.speaker: KAITLEN
dialogues.text: (standing up, livid) Get away from her you fat misogynist pig! Brooke looks to Kaitlen: Get OUT of here! EXT. JOHNSON COUNTY WATER TREATMENT FACILITY — NIGHT Boyd Bolton holds the créme brulee torch in his hands. LAURA (V.O., CONT’D) His friends abandoned him too. Boyd kisses the créme brulee torch and then THROWS it int the waste treatment pond. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: BOYD
dialogues.text: I will always love you, Laura Pickler. The créme brulee torch bobs along the nasty surface of th water. INT. PICKLER HOME — LATER Laura stares at herself in the mirror. She seems less severe, a bit more relaxed. LAURA (V.O., CONT’D) Most people would have given up under those conditions. Laura smiles at herself in the mirror. EXT. HIGHWAY — LATER Laura drives her Suburban. She speaks to five KIDS with special needs.

dialogues.speaker: LAURA
dialogues.text: But not this man. This man finally sold his recipe to the one thousand and ninth restaurant he visited - his secret recipe. The Kids are hanging off every word of her story. INT. COMMUNITY POOL — DAY The five kids with special needs, wearing CAMP BUTTER SWIMMING CAPS, swim the backstroke. LAURA (V.O., CONT’D) And we know that old man today... as Colonel Sanders of the world famous Kentucky Fried Chicken. So my point is, that I suppose it is okay to lose every once in a while. Laura cheers on the Camp Butter kids as they race against each other. INT. KENTUCKY FRIED CHICKEN — LATER Laura, dining with the kids from Camp Butter, eats a drumstick. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: LAURA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And I have one person to thank for teaching me that - Laura wipes fried chicken from her mouth with a wet-nap. LAURA (V.O., CONT’D) - Destiny. Pleased, she rounds up the kids and exits, a new woman. EXT. IOWA CORN FIELD — DAY Destiny rides her bike past another vast cornfield.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, I didn’t win State... INT. PIONEER HALL — IOWA STATE FAIR - STATE Destiny holds up a RED SECOND PLACE RIBBON. She stands ne to NED EATON, who holds a BLUE RIBBON.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I came in second. But that’s okay. Second place is pretty good. INT. EMMIT HOUSE — CHRISTMAS Jill, Ethan, Hayden, and Destiny eat a big Christmas dinner.

dialogues.speaker: JILL
dialogues.text: Hayden, would you like to start us off with a Christmas carol?

dialogues.speaker: HAYDEN
dialogues.text: No thank you, I’m celebrating Kwanzaa this year. Hayden puts an Afro-centric crown on his head.

dialogues.speaker: DESTINY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh, and Miss Jill and Mr. Ethan adopted me which is nice because I was kind of getting tired of moving. Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 104 DESTINY’S BEDROOM — Her SUITCASE is wedged way, way in the back of her closet She hasn’t used it in awhile. EXT. CORNFIELD — DAY Destiny and Hayden rides their bikes through the cornfiel and past another cow. As they ride out of frame, we stay with the cow. We get closer. And closer. And closer. The cow looks at us, thinking her deep, deep cow thoughts until we FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: THE END
dialogues.text: Script provided for educational purposes. More scripts ca
